posts.name: JoeyD
posts.cooked:
Hey, my name is Joey and I am the mentor that runs the CheesyCare group for Team 254. Our mission at competitions is to go out and assist teams at the event and make sure every robot is playing at its best. Nobody likes having a robot that dies on the field , having mechanisms that aren’t working the way we had hoped , or generally just being unreliable . I’ve been there and it’s not fun (at least for me). In that spirit, here is a list of the most common things that our crew saw and helped teams with, and what we did or recommend doing about it. My goal is to make this a useful resource for teams before their first events. Sorry in advance for the novel!

Bumpers Gaps: make sure your bumpers meet the rules about exposed sections of frame perimeter. This year the rule was 0.5” and we had to make 1” wide bumper segments multiple times this season. Mounting: design them in from the beginning! It is hard to do as an afterthought. Rivet-nuts and bolts are an easy and relatively robust solution that is my default implementation at events. This video is similar, but normally we just bolt the bumper down directly into the nut. The permanent stud method can also be achieved with a regular nut or preferably a nylock nut in place of the rivet nut. Reversible bumpers: I don’t recommend them. There is convenience to not having to remove your bumpers between matches, but if you commit to the reversible style, they really need to be well executed and done before the competition. Flappy bits: make sure the flaps are fully secured and cannot catch on field elements/other robots/the floor. On several robots, we ended up stapling the colors down each time and pulling the staples to change colors between matches Weight: extra fabric in reversible bumpers can push teams over the weight limit, requiring creative solutions for weight reduction Repairs: they are harder to fix at competitions than regular bumpers. Taping tears can be more complex

Gaps: make sure your bumpers meet the rules about exposed sections of frame perimeter. This year the rule was 0.5” and we had to make 1” wide bumper segments multiple times this season.

Mounting: design them in from the beginning! It is hard to do as an afterthought. Rivet-nuts and bolts are an easy and relatively robust solution that is my default implementation at events. This video is similar, but normally we just bolt the bumper down directly into the nut. The permanent stud method can also be achieved with a regular nut or preferably a nylock nut in place of the rivet nut.

Reversible bumpers: I don’t recommend them. There is convenience to not having to remove your bumpers between matches, but if you commit to the reversible style, they really need to be well executed and done before the competition. Flappy bits: make sure the flaps are fully secured and cannot catch on field elements/other robots/the floor. On several robots, we ended up stapling the colors down each time and pulling the staples to change colors between matches Weight: extra fabric in reversible bumpers can push teams over the weight limit, requiring creative solutions for weight reduction Repairs: they are harder to fix at competitions than regular bumpers. Taping tears can be more complex

Flappy bits: make sure the flaps are fully secured and cannot catch on field elements/other robots/the floor. On several robots, we ended up stapling the colors down each time and pulling the staples to change colors between matches

Weight: extra fabric in reversible bumpers can push teams over the weight limit, requiring creative solutions for weight reduction

Repairs: they are harder to fix at competitions than regular bumpers. Taping tears can be more complex

NEOs/Sparks Losing settings/configs across robot restarts/power cycles: usually our solution was to replace the motor controller and that would resolve the issue Controller stopped responding entirely: not sure the root cause so we would replace the controller and the new one would work with the same configs/settings. Fragile encoder/halls wires : these need to be handled with care and not pulled from the wires. I learned what a disconnected/intermittent motor phase connection sounds like on a NEO this year, it sounds like gears grinding as the motor jumps back and forth as it tries to spin. Not really actionable info here, just a tip for those debugging robots, make sure all of the phases are connected solidly. Sparks friction fit connectors for CAN and the halls/encoder: this is a pretty common failure point and we strongly encourage teams to hot glue in these connectors.

Losing settings/configs across robot restarts/power cycles: usually our solution was to replace the motor controller and that would resolve the issue

Controller stopped responding entirely: not sure the root cause so we would replace the controller and the new one would work with the same configs/settings.

Fragile encoder/halls wires : these need to be handled with care and not pulled from the wires.

I learned what a disconnected/intermittent motor phase connection sounds like on a NEO this year, it sounds like gears grinding as the motor jumps back and forth as it tries to spin. Not really actionable info here, just a tip for those debugging robots, make sure all of the phases are connected solidly.

Sparks friction fit connectors for CAN and the halls/encoder: this is a pretty common failure point and we strongly encourage teams to hot glue in these connectors.

Vortexes I didn’t see that many of these used this year, so not a lot to report here. Wobbly shafts : the most robust use we saw was them mounted directly to a hex shaft constrained on both sides of the motor. Controller lock ups: Only really remember seeing this once, but a motor/controller was not responding (including status lights) and a robot reboot fixed the issue.

I didn’t see that many of these used this year, so not a lot to report here.

Wobbly shafts : the most robust use we saw was them mounted directly to a hex shaft constrained on both sides of the motor.

Controller lock ups: Only really remember seeing this once, but a motor/controller was not responding (including status lights) and a robot reboot fixed the issue.

Krakens Current limits: make sure the current limits are low enough that the robot isn’t browning out by the end of the match Screw terminals: loose screws on either the CAN or power lines cause issues. There is a torque spec from WCP that can help

Current limits: make sure the current limits are low enough that the robot isn’t browning out by the end of the match

Screw terminals: loose screws on either the CAN or power lines cause issues. There is a torque spec from WCP that can help

Falcons Also didn’t see many of these or issues with these. From past years: watch out for too long of mounting screws binding up the motor and the internal split shaft coming loose.

Also didn’t see many of these or issues with these.

From past years: watch out for too long of mounting screws binding up the motor and the internal split shaft coming loose.

Climbers This was our most common subsystem to work with teams on this year. There are a lot of great off-the- shelf kits these days that make it relatively simple to put together a functional climber. They are all pretty similar and have similar issues. Gearing: make sure the gearbox has both enough torque to lift the robot and also enough to prevent the robot from dropping within the 5 second window at the end of the match. This was usually accomplished via adding stages or swapping out planetary gearboxes. Also make sure your motors are in brake mode! This helps a lot. Ropes snapping: especially with that high-torque climbing system, ropes going over sharp edges of metal will fray and cut quickly. Make sure that the rope is running on pulleys and not just sliding over the edge of a hole . CG vs lifting point: if the climber is not over CG of the robot, the robot will pivot until it is so (unless you have a reaction point). Make sure that the climber behaves the way you expect in testing Binding/friction: sometimes these fail to extend either due to over clamped hardware or bent parts after taking a hard knock. Some grease and checking clamping forces is usually all that’s needed to sort this out.

This was our most common subsystem to work with teams on this year. There are a lot of great off-the- shelf kits these days that make it relatively simple to put together a functional climber. They are all pretty similar and have similar issues.

Gearing: make sure the gearbox has both enough torque to lift the robot and also enough to prevent the robot from dropping within the 5 second window at the end of the match. This was usually accomplished via adding stages or swapping out planetary gearboxes. Also make sure your motors are in brake mode! This helps a lot.

Ropes snapping: especially with that high-torque climbing system, ropes going over sharp edges of metal will fray and cut quickly. Make sure that the rope is running on pulleys and not just sliding over the edge of a hole .

CG vs lifting point: if the climber is not over CG of the robot, the robot will pivot until it is so (unless you have a reaction point). Make sure that the climber behaves the way you expect in testing

Binding/friction: sometimes these fail to extend either due to over clamped hardware or bent parts after taking a hard knock. Some grease and checking clamping forces is usually all that’s needed to sort this out.

Driver stations There is velcro on the driver stations at the field . It is beneficial to put the mating velcro on the underside of your driver station console to prevent it from coming off of the wall when the wall gets hit and shakes Power: bring the laptop charger to the field every time. Always have your driver station plugged into power during every match so the laptop never dies.

There is velcro on the driver stations at the field . It is beneficial to put the mating velcro on the underside of your driver station console to prevent it from coming off of the wall when the wall gets hit and shakes

Power: bring the laptop charger to the field every time. Always have your driver station plugged into power during every match so the laptop never dies.

Swerve Drives Maintenance: while I love the prevalence of COTS swerve modules, they do still need maintenance. Use loctite : loose screws causes modules to shift or fall apart entirely Grease your gears : proper greasing ensures your gears will last as long as possible Don’t skip critical components : spacers, plates, snap rings, and hardware are all critical components and need to be there to keep your modules running smoothly

Maintenance: while I love the prevalence of COTS swerve modules, they do still need maintenance. Use loctite : loose screws causes modules to shift or fall apart entirely Grease your gears : proper greasing ensures your gears will last as long as possible Don’t skip critical components : spacers, plates, snap rings, and hardware are all critical components and need to be there to keep your modules running smoothly

Use loctite : loose screws causes modules to shift or fall apart entirely

Grease your gears : proper greasing ensures your gears will last as long as possible

Don’t skip critical components : spacers, plates, snap rings, and hardware are all critical components and need to be there to keep your modules running smoothly

KOP Chassis (AM14UX) (oddly specific but also oddly common issue) Both bearing flanges should end up inside the drive gearbox so they cannot fall out. I have seen a remarkable number of robots with at least the top bearing (for the gearbox cluster shaft) falling out because it has been installed backwards.

Both bearing flanges should end up inside the drive gearbox so they cannot fall out. I have seen a remarkable number of robots with at least the top bearing (for the gearbox cluster shaft) falling out because it has been installed backwards.

Major Structural Damage This last one is hard to be specific about, but as the robots get more powerful and faster we see a lot of bent drivetrain rails and exploded/bent intakes. Frame rails :  bring spares of your (usually 1x2) frame rails! We upped ours (on 254) to 1x3 this year and had a solid 1x1 bar across the front of our intake behind the bumper to reinforce it. I know other teams had solid 1x1s or 1x2s to do the same thing. (our frame rail from last year , didn’t find any good pics from this year) If you can remove your bent frame rail, it can often be straightened in the machine shop at least once. We occasionally would even then re-install the frame rails backwards so they bowed out instead of in and then a few matches later it would be mostly straight. Intake rollers: same thing goes here, anything exposed to other robots will get bent, broken, and beat up.

This last one is hard to be specific about, but as the robots get more powerful and faster we see a lot of bent drivetrain rails and exploded/bent intakes.

Frame rails :  bring spares of your (usually 1x2) frame rails! We upped ours (on 254) to 1x3 this year and had a solid 1x1 bar across the front of our intake behind the bumper to reinforce it. I know other teams had solid 1x1s or 1x2s to do the same thing. (our frame rail from last year , didn’t find any good pics from this year) If you can remove your bent frame rail, it can often be straightened in the machine shop at least once. We occasionally would even then re-install the frame rails backwards so they bowed out instead of in and then a few matches later it would be mostly straight.

If you can remove your bent frame rail, it can often be straightened in the machine shop at least once. We occasionally would even then re-install the frame rails backwards so they bowed out instead of in and then a few matches later it would be mostly straight.

Intake rollers: same thing goes here, anything exposed to other robots will get bent, broken, and beat up.

A lot of the most common issues we see come from wiring/electrical stuff so I figured it deserved its own section.

CAN issues Loose connections are the biggest issues here and the hardest to find. We recommend soldering all of your CAN connections except where necessary for robot serviceability. The terminating resistor coming loose can also cause “weird” CAN issues that can be hard to track down. If you are having trouble isolating the issue in the chain, check the connection to your resistor.

Loose connections are the biggest issues here and the hardest to find. We recommend soldering all of your CAN connections except where necessary for robot serviceability.

The terminating resistor coming loose can also cause “weird” CAN issues that can be hard to track down. If you are having trouble isolating the issue in the chain, check the connection to your resistor.

Battery screw terminals Gotta make sure all of those connections are really locked down well. A loose battery or main breaker screw connection can lead to disconnects and robots sitting dead on the field. Main breaker cover : side note, make sure the main breaker is protected from being hit by stray game pieces, robots doing the wrong things, and just general debris ( alt design )

Gotta make sure all of those connections are really locked down well. A loose battery or main breaker screw connection can lead to disconnects and robots sitting dead on the field.

Main breaker cover : side note, make sure the main breaker is protected from being hit by stray game pieces, robots doing the wrong things, and just general debris ( alt design )

Wires Check that wires aren’t underconstrained (and liable to get caught on moving robot parts /game pieces/other robots/etc or overconstrained and pulled super tightly and coming out of connectors because of it. Slow rubbing on moving components is also hazardous . Examples of properly constrained wires . Inertia from hard impacts can be enough to disconnect wires/connections Zip tie (or otherwise secure with hardware ) anderson powerpole leads together

Check that wires aren’t underconstrained (and liable to get caught on moving robot parts /game pieces/other robots/etc or overconstrained and pulled super tightly and coming out of connectors because of it. Slow rubbing on moving components is also hazardous . Examples of properly constrained wires .

Inertia from hard impacts can be enough to disconnect wires/connections

Zip tie (or otherwise secure with hardware ) anderson powerpole leads together

Hot gluing connections We hot glue every ethernet connection (just a dab under the latch or on the sides so it cannot come out, do NOT make it impossible to remove), every USB connection ( CANivore , rio , etc), and any other non-latching connectors ( good ethernet example , bad ethernet example ) When working with teams we strongly encourage them to hot glue every connection on the SparkMaxes

We hot glue every ethernet connection (just a dab under the latch or on the sides so it cannot come out, do NOT make it impossible to remove), every USB connection ( CANivore , rio , etc), and any other non-latching connectors ( good ethernet example , bad ethernet example )

When working with teams we strongly encourage them to hot glue every connection on the SparkMaxes

WAGO lever nuts These are more of a solution than a problem, I love them for quick fixes and they work great in FRC . A couple notes for them are: They don’t last forever, there is a finite number of cycles latching and unlatching before they wear out They are actually only rated for 30A so just be mindful. That said, I have never seen issues, even when they are the power connections for Krakens

These are more of a solution than a problem, I love them for quick fixes and they work great in FRC . A couple notes for them are: They don’t last forever, there is a finite number of cycles latching and unlatching before they wear out They are actually only rated for 30A so just be mindful. That said, I have never seen issues, even when they are the power connections for Krakens

They don’t last forever, there is a finite number of cycles latching and unlatching before they wear out

They are actually only rated for 30A so just be mindful. That said, I have never seen issues, even when they are the power connections for Krakens

Batteries: Zip tie your primary battery connector ! Yes we cut it every match or use a reusable zip tie. Alternatively you can use a bracket and bolt Old batteries: these new more powerful motors really want to use the max power from the battery. Most manufacturers recommend replacing batteries after 3 years.

Zip tie your primary battery connector ! Yes we cut it every match or use a reusable zip tie. Alternatively you can use a bracket and bolt

Old batteries: these new more powerful motors really want to use the max power from the battery. Most manufacturers recommend replacing batteries after 3 years.

Cover the ports on your roborio! Electrical tape is the easiest thing to do to prevent metal shavings getting in there and wreaking havoc on your rio.

Drop testing: this isn’t an issue, more of a diagnosis tool that I wanted to share. We drop our own robot and anyone else’s who is having issues. We take one side at a time and lift it up about 6” from a hard floor. With people watching all of the relevant status lights (radio, rio, CAN , motor controllers, encoders, etc) the robot gets dropped 3-4 times per side. Ideally this is done while connected to the driver station and usually while enabled (with someone ready to hit the disable key). This provides maximum information to the people debugging the robot when any statuses change.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: Great post, bookmarked and shared to the teams I know that don’t have CD . Love the pictures of everything, especially the Ethernet glue - I always struggle to explain that particular concept when talking about hot gluing connections.

posts.name: Eugene Fang
posts.cooked:
This is probably my favorite CD post of the year. Thanks Joey!

JoeyD:

or otherwise secure with hardware

We’ve found that these can pop out. 100% recommend going with the zip tie route instead.

posts.name: Pizzatc
posts.cooked:
JoeyD:

Major Structural Damage

I’m going to add onto this a little bit. One area which I think which a lot of teams struggle with is designing their bots for stiffness. Impacts with other robots have gotten worse with the introduction of motors with high torques leading to impacts with higher energies. Designing your robot to be stiff and handle these forces is one way to limit damage.

My advice generally for teams is have a dedicated time to just look at your CAD and try to consider what would happen if a robot at peak acceleration hit your mechanism and wonder if it would survive. If it does great if not take some times and try to design it be able to to somewhat handle the impact better.

There’s not a fixed list of what to look for but from my experience I look at joints, fasteners, supports.

posts.name: Cooper Surma
posts.cooked:
JoeyD:

Vortexes

One thing I want to bring up regarding the vortexes  is that teams have had the faceplates on the motors crack when using them on MK4is.

How have Vortexes been for you? General Forum

How have Vortexes been for you? General Forum

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
JoeyD:

Swerve Drives

Maintenance

Calibration before each event (and before playoffs) to make sure all of your steering encoders are accurate. Check your wheel tread after every match. In our case we burned up one wheel badly because it was off by 5° during quals at our first event. We didn’t check til after inspection for playoffs. We learned. Our second event the wheels were replaced during alliance selection but they were all in better shape

IMG_4062 1920×1280 81.3 KB

IMG_4062 1920×1280 81.3 KB

IMG_4062 1920×1280 81.3 KB

“Racing Slicks”

These can be used as maxspline intake wheels now (not for a note because way too fragile)

JoeyD:

There is velcro on the driver stations at the field .

Funny story about that. We were getting some help from Cheesy Care with our hangers. They put Velcro on our laptop. Except it was the wrong type of Velcro. So it was soft on soft. Our laptop fell off after a hard hit from the other alliance

On a serious note, thank you so much for your help. Even though we never got the hang, it was really fun to work with some of the best in FRC .

posts.custom_user_title: Some people call me the Space Cowboy

posts.cooked:
JoeyD:

Reversible bumpers: I don’t recommend them. There is convenience to not having to remove your bumpers between matches, but if you commit to the reversible style, they really need to be well executed and done before the competition.

What my team does is we have one bumper(blue) and we have Velcro that we can put on top of it for the red bumpers, semi reversible we find it’s amazing for quick turnarounds

posts.name: Ankur Raghavan
posts.cooked:
JoeyD:

Zip tie your primary battery connector ! Yes we cut it every match or use a reusable zip tie. Alternatively you can use a bracket and bolt

I’ve seen this been recommended a few times, but our main connectors were very difficult to separate. Is it still recommended to zip tie it? Does the force lessen as you use it more?

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
Ankur-Raghavan:

Is it still recommended to zip tie it? Does the force lessen as you use it more?

Yes, ziptie it every single match. From my experience teams can either take this advice and apply it every match or learn the hard way (like we did in 2013) and lose a critical match when your battery comes unplugged.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
Eugene_Fang:

that these can pop out.

I only use them when I can wrap them in electrical tape (1 loop all the way around). They are better than just tape. I’ve moved us to mostly 4" zipties.

Edit: “But the SB50 Feels hard to disconnect” - yes, to your puny human hands. 50g impact don’t care. Loose battery dont care. Ziptie or bolt the sb50 every time.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
Pizzatc:

wonder if it would survive.

We actually never updated the mechanical design of our utb intake frame, because the leading beam would bend over the course of matches without affecting performance, the damage stayed isolated to the single bar, and then we would swap the single bar.

If we reinforced it back to the drive frame, we could have transmitted more damage farther back into the swerves and into more complicated machined parts that we didn’t have spares for, so would not have been able to replace between matches.

posts.name: Ankur Raghavan
posts.cooked:
Pizzatc:

Designing your robot to be stiff and handle these forces is one way to limit damage

Using a Bellypan and adding crossbars is a pretty easy way to maintain a fairly light bot but reduce damage a lot. We had no chassis damage across 2 regionals and champs on regular maxtube. To be fair we didn’t have an under bumper intake, which contributed to much of the damage found on other bots. IMG_7442 1658×1658 481 KB

IMG_7442 1658×1658 481 KB

IMG_7442 1658×1658 481 KB

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked:
JoeyD:

They are actually only rated for 30A so just be mindful. That said, I have never seen issues, even when they are the power connections for Krakens

It is my understanding (someone more knowledgeable pls correct if wrong) that the 30A rating is for 24/7/365 constant load inside of a house (or something). For FRC purposes, these are both allowed for 40A connections (there is Q&A precedent), and will work just as well if not better than a PP45 for carrying large amounts of current.

Also, how many pounds of hot glue did y’all use this last season.

posts.name: Pat Mattin
posts.cooked:
Better than the half and half reversible bumpers, but how much quicker is it than replacing sets? Does that minor time save make the risk of losing the cover in the middle of a match worth it?

I also find that we want the bumpers off a lot of the time anyways. They can get in the way of some repairs and it’s easier to spot where the frame is starting to bend.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
JoeyD:

WAGO lever nuts … are actually only rated for 30A

This has been discussed before:

Electrical Connectors for FRC FIRST

Robust Electrical and Wiring Practices Technical Discussion

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: And the SB50 battery connector is rated for 50 A continuous…

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
kingc95:

These can be used as maxspline intake wheels

Yeah, they can be.  We had a lot of used swerve wheels from last year.

IMG_20240328_161315 1920×1440 213 KB

IMG_20240328_161315 1920×1440 213 KB

All the tips above were what we’d do.  We did use rtv clear silicone instead of hot glue in lots of places which worked well too.  Before that we had a CAN connector in a SparkMax with a low ID disconnect causing the drive Vortexs to not configure right from code. It was the first time I’ve had a missing device with the bus intact cause so much havoc.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
